Source: vehicle_manual.txt p2
reference: When engine cranks but won't start, check these in order of likelihood: (1) Fuel system - verify fuel level and pump operation, test fuel pressure at 40-50 PSI [Citation: Para 1-2.1, Table 1-1]. (2) Ignition system - test for spark at plugs [Citation: Para 1-2.3]. (3) Air intake - inspect for severe restrictions [Citation: Para 1-2]. WARNING: Fuel system under pressure, wear eye protection [Safety Notice 1-A].

9.6V minimum CCA Rating 600 minimum Load Test Duration 15 seconds Replacement Interval 48-60 months --- PAGE 5 --- SECTION 2: COOLING SYSTEM Para 2-1: Cooling System Overview The cooling system maintains engine temperature between 180-220°F using liquid coolant circulation. Syste
Source: vehicle_manual.txt p5
reference: Engine overheating (gauge above 220°F) has several probable causes: (1) Low coolant level - 50% probability, check reservoir when cold [Citation: Para 2-2.1]. (2) Thermostat failure - 25% probability, test if upper hose gets hot at 195°F [Citation: Para 2-2.2]. (3) Water pump failure - 15% probability, inspect for leaks and bearing noise [Citation: Para 2-2.3]. (4) Radiator blockage - 10% probability. WARNING: Never open cooling system when hot, wait 30 minutes minimum [Safety Notice 2-A].

4-3] Step 2: Locate source of draw Remove fuses one at a time Monitor ammeter when each fuse removed --- PAGE 14 --- When amperage drops to normal, circuit found Inspect components on that circuit [Citation: Para 4-3.2] Step 3: Test battery condition Fully charge battery (12.6V+ 
Source: vehicle_manual.txt p14
reference: Test alternator charging: Connect voltmeter to battery terminals, start engine and increase RPM to 2000. Voltage should read 13.8-14.4V. Below 13.8V indicates alternator not charging. Above 14.8V indicates regulator failure - turn off engine immediately and disconnect battery [Citation: Para 4-2.2, Table 4-1]. WARNING: Overcharging above 14.8V can cause battery explosion [Safety Notice 4-A].

Alarm P0420 summary:
PSI Fuel Pressure (WOT) 35 PSI minimum Pump Flow Rate 30 GPH minimum Filter Replacement 15,000 miles --- PAGE 18 --- Component Specification Injector Resistance 12-16 ohms Tank Capacity 16 gallons SECTION 6: DIAGNOSTIC TROUBLE CODES Para 6-1: OBD-II Code Overview On-Board Diagnos
Source: vehicle_manual.txt p18
reference: Code P0420 indicates 'Catalyst System Efficiency Below Threshold' - the catalytic converter is not operating at required efficiency [Citation: Para 6-2]. Possible causes: (1) Catalytic converter degradation (most common), (2) Oxygen sensor failure, (3) Exhaust leak before catalyst, (4) Engine running too rich [Citation: Para 6-2]. Verify by monitoring O2 sensor operation - downstream sensor should be steady around 0.45V; if it fluctuates like upstream sensor, converter has failed [Citation: Para 6-2.2].

low exact procedures. Do not attempt repairs without proper training and tools. [Safety Notice 3- A] --- PAGE 8 --- Components: Master cylinder (dual circuit design) Brake fluid: DOT 3 specification Front disc brakes (ventilated rotors) Rear drum brakes Parking brake (mechanical 
Source: vehicle_manual.txt p8
reference: Yes, this is a safety-critical condition. Brake pedal sinking to floor indicates probable master cylinder failure (60% probability) or external fluid leak (30% probability) [Citation: Para 3-2]. Check brake fluid level immediately - low fluid is an emergency condition [Safety Notice 3-B]. If master cylinder failure confirmed, vehicle must be towed - do not attempt to drive as brake failure can occur without warning [Safety Notice 3-C].

Source: vehicle_manual.txt p6
reference: To test thermostat: Start engine from cold and monitor upper radiator hose temperature. Hose should become hot when temperature gauge reaches 195°F (thermostat opening temperature) [Citation: Table 2-1]. If hose stays cold, thermostat is stuck closed and preventing coolant circulation [Citation: Para 2-2.2].

eration Monitor O2 sensor voltages with scan tool Upstream sensor: should fluctuate 0.1-0.9V rapidly --- PAGE 19 --- Downstream sensor: should be steady around 0.45V If downstream sensor fluctuates like upstream, converter failed [Citation: Para 6-2.2, Figure 6-1] Step 3: Inspect
Source: vehicle_manual.txt p19
reference: Code P0171 'System Too Lean (Bank 1)' indicates engine running with insufficient fuel or excessive air [Citation: Para 6-3]. Possible causes: (1) Vacuum leak at intake manifold or brake booster hose, (2) Mass airflow sensor contamination, (3) Weak fuel pump or clogged filter, (4) Faulty oxygen sensor, (5) Exhaust leak before O2 sensor [Citation: Para 6-3]. Diagnose by checking for vacuum leaks first (listen for hissing, spray carburetor cleaner around gaskets), then inspect MAF sensor [Citation: Para 6-3.1, Para 6-3.2].
